title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in India before 1 January 2017?
preds:
i feel this question is malformed. the following is the quote from early warning project page. 
"Mass atrocities are rare yet devastating crimes. They are also preventable. "
But what is predicted below are terrorist attacks :(. 
Another miss and probably biggest mistake is Indians is not single identity like US/Australia/UK etc. the apt comparison for India should be EU, with each state having its own identity & culture. 
in such a diverse environment no one will be able to sense the local opinions and moods from living in another part of the country. if possible split the question in to sub section of India then it would be possible to have realistic predictions.
There's not much time left, and no indication that strange things will happen.
Lot of instability in India right now, currency move big disaster, big mistake...
I'm watching for a backlash over currency and cash shortage on payday, but short of that I don't expect any outlying problems in the extreme NE of West to erupt. 2% is too low though.
Crisis watch update Aug. - Oct: low levels of violence in Non-Kashmire India and in India.

An interesting bonus of the recent demonetization move by the Indian government, on the 1000 and 500 rupee notes, might be that it will bring peace to Kashmir in the short run, perhaps for the next 1 year or so until counterfeiting gets going again. http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/currency-ban-has-ended-terror-funding-stone-pelting-says-manohar-parrikar-1625527
"Earlier, there were rates: Rs. 500 for stone pelting (on security forces in Kashmir) and Rs. 1,000 for doing something else. PM has brought terror funding to zero." Dropping 2% to 1%, which is as low as I will go on most questions.

India in general is considered a "flawed, but stable democracy", and therefore it can be hard to conceptualize how an episode of mass killing might occur. However, there are a large number of smaller ethnic groups that don't necessarily interact much with the central government, and which might have rough feelings with other ethnic groups. It don't think that a mass killing is *likely*, but I'll put it at a non-zero chance. Also note: India does have a history of mass killings. It's not unheard of. http://www.earlywarningproject.com/2015/05/05/india-s-gujarat-faces-atrocity-risks-despite-new-development-efforts

Currently, even though policies aimed at marginalizing minorities have been passed on the local and regional levels, the national government is stable and has a progressive and popular agenda across parties. Additionally, with current changes to make elections more transparent, India is not likely to see new episode by this January.

India has responded with counter terrorism measures after a long time. India has also managed to create diplomatic ripples that have started to pressurise Pakistan within SAARC at least if not at a global level. Given these circumstances, a terror strike seems very likely
Not enough time to reverse the downward trends in violence over the last few years.

August crisis watch reports:
-Non-Kashmir: July 10, 10 soldiers killed by Moaist rebels, and 3 insurgents killed by police.
-Kashmir: Aug 15, 5 killed by police, and Aug 31, Security forces kill 1 bringing the total to 69 since violence started in July.
...

In line with consensus and new border security measures that means infiltrators from Pakistan will likely be killed at the border. "The Centre has okayed a five-layer elaborate plan to completely stop infiltration on the 2,900-km western border with Pakistan. It entails round-the-clock surveillance through sophisticated technology which in effect will totally "lock" India's western border to prevent Pathankot-like terror attacks and smuggling. CCTV cameras, thermal image and night-vision devices, battlefield surveillance radar, underground monitoring sensors and laser barriers will be placed along the border to track all movement from the other side. The integrated set-up will ensure that if one device doesn't work, another will alert the control room in case of a transgression, officials said. Laser barriers will cover 130 unfenced sections including riverine and mountain terrain from Jammu & Kashmir to Gujarat — often used by the infiltrators.Laser barriers will cover 130 unfenced sections, including remote riverine and mountain terrain, from J&K to Gujarat. "
http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/India-plans-five-layer-lock-at-Pakistan-border/articleshow/51770756.cms Army to deploy remote-controlled guns at LoC to take on infiltrators 
http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/army-to-deploy-remote-controlled-guns-at-loc-to-take-on-infiltrators/story-HDBgHHXgSsYzvyDeGOqDmO.html
One mass killing in the last 20 years (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_massacres_in_India)

Festering violence in Kashmir over the past two months due to surge in secessionist tendencies has led to the deaths of 68 people and over 10,000 injured so far. This is one geography where historical reasons and near-term escalation of discord may cause an episode of widespread civilian deaths to qualify as mass killing. However, statistically, an episode of mass killing within a twelve month timeframe has not occurred in Kashmir, even though cumulatively there have been over 40,000 fatalities over a 25 year period. Mass killing within the purview of the definition is unlikely to happen within the timeframe mentioned.  The Naxalite-Maoist insurgency is another potential candidate for a mass killing. Even though total casualties exceeding 1000 in a year have happened before (2009, 2010), noncombatant deaths have never been close to a mass killing episode. This remains, however, a potential risk, given historical reasons.  The other geography at risk is the Indian North East, where intermittent clashes have led to episodes of civilian deaths over the years.  Terrorist acts have led to widespread deaths in single locations but have fallen short of the EWP's definition of mass killing.  In recent years, wins, or alliances, with nationalist parties has stoked reactionary sentiment, increasing the likelihood of escalation in armed conflicts .   A common thread running across the above cited instances is the demographic of the affected. They tend to be marginalised minorities, tribals, and the historically oppressed. Geographies with high densities of this demographic tend to be at higher risk of falling under the definition here. However, as things stand today, difficult to see a high likelihood of an episode of mass killing before Jan'17. The 5% probability reflects Kashmir, predominantly.

There have been religious and ethnical motivated killings in India in the past. However, these have often been fuelled  by politicians who were trying to find scapegoats for economic and social problems. Despite a continuously social divide and crimes against women, India does not seem to encounter any major internal security and conflict challenges. The ongoing dispute over Kashmir could prove to become a challenge for internal security in the future if not resolved soon.
Nothing has happened recently. Security in India is tight.
I would like it to be 0% chance.
Pakistan government needs distraction and push militants to act

Threshold is 1000 killed in a new mass casualty even before January 1, 2017.  Seems extremely unlikely based on occurrence of past mass causality events: https://www.start.umd.edu/gtd/search/Results.aspx?chart=casualties&casualties_type=b&casualties_max=&dtp2=all&country=92
No indication this will occur before Jan 1, 2017
the forecast is about state led mass killings of more than 1000 non-combatant civilians. Highly unlikely in the republic of India

Please see my initial take on this question for the background on this post
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/299647 Once winter sets in about 2-3 months time, it becomes almost impossible to cross over into the Kashmir valley from across the border, due to the heavy snow fall. This drastically reduces the time window available, if there are to be any major disruptions in the valley this year. Also the tension in the valley now seems to have plateaued out, after threatening to do some serious damage in the initial days of unrest following Wani's death.  Considering all this, think it makes sense to reduce my forecast from 4% to 2%.

According to the EWP's definitions of civilian casualties: The last time 1 000 civilians died was in 2008. This year 136 have died, so assuming deaths continue on the same trend, 272 would be the full year trend. News reports also indicate substantial downturn in violent deaths. http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/india/database/indiafatalities.htm
http://www.earlywarningproject.com/definitions Assam Witnesses Lowest Civilians Deaths In 25 Years Due To Extremism: Report
http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/assam-witnesses-lowest-civilians-deaths-in-25-years-due-to-extremism-report-1442701 J-K: Civilian deaths in terrorism-related violence down by 90% 
http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/j-k-civilian-deaths-in-terrorism-related-violence-down-by-90/story-bRqpKWB56KmeziiRjbNXBO.html http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/AR(E)1516.pdf Early warning project 2016 has Bharat ranked in the middle.Seems unlikely. http://www.earlywarningproject.com/2016/01/11/2016-wikisurvey-results

Recent news items regarding attacks on those transporting/killing cattle? Crisis watch splits Kashmir from the rest of India.
Non -Kashmiri violence seems related to clashes with Moaist rebels and the number of civilian casualties is extremely low (<5 / mo).
Kashmiri violence is related to cross border fire with Pakistan. Civilians are generally not targeted, and fatalities are less tha 5 per month.  Crisis watch quotes the Pakistani FM indicating that 87 Pakistani were killed since Jan. 2010.
In July 2016, security crackdowns related to protests in Jammu & Kashmir resulted in the deaths of 49 civilians. Additional security and curfews were imposed on the area.  Another 900+ fatalities by year end seems unlikely.

Off the top of my head, the present situation in Kashmir valley is worth watching. Think there hasn't been as serious an unrest there for more than a decade. However, security forces have learned from that bitter experience (terrorists crossing over from across the border) and have plugged most of those easy crossing points in the years since. On the whole, I think it is unlikely to devolve into the open season for terrorists that it was in the 1990 decade time frame.  I don't see any other conflict producing 1000 deaths in the time frame of this question. If you extend the one year horizon out to 4-5 years and maintain the 1000 death threshold, there are some other conflicts also that will enter the picture like the Maoist insurgency, multiple North East groups and perhaps even some communal conflagration as happened in Gujarat in 2002. But that is not what this question is looking for. Initiating coverage at 4%.
malih bombaških napada da ali ništa spektakularno
